posts.name: Sherry Betcher
posts.cooked: We built the KitBot. Today was the first day of our 2nd event. Our shooter strangely worked fine during the first few matches (and during our 1st event). But then started working only during auton , but during tellyop, the shooter was not shooting high enough to make it into the speaker. It’s shooting roughly 2 feet lower during teleop than it had during our auton. Please share ideas why this might be the case. We’re planning to troubleshoot in the morning. TIA

First thing I’d do is check your batteries. Are they low during the match? Check with a battery beak.

Second thing is logging (if you’re not already). What does the velocity, output voltage, and Vbus of the shooter look like?

Third thing: standard mechanical checkup. Is anything shearing or grinding? Grease dries up midmatch? Think of anything and think outside the box. Also ensure to check if anything is bent , bowed or sagging.

Code is the last thing I’d check (very unlikely). Did you accidentally change the teleop shoot command to 80% or something?

posts.name: Sherry Betcher
posts.cooked: Thank you for helping.Follow up questions please. Battery- it is freshly charged each time we start. But during the match, it strangely rapidly changes power levels during the match. It goes up and down from 11 down to about 8. We have no idea why that might happen? Logging- how do we check those values you mention for our shooter?

CoachBet:

But during the match, it strangely rapidly changes power levels during the match. It goes up and down from 11 down to about 8

You have electrical issues and there can be a variety of causes. I would start by inspecting the battery to PDH path, check for high resistance, poor crimps, loose lug nuts, or damaged cables.

As in it’s at 8 Volts at the end of the match? Wildly oscillating voltage makes perfect sense. You’re drawing power from the motors, which uses current, which causes voltage drops.

But if it’s 8V at the end, your batteries are bad or you’ve got an electrical issue.

CoachBet:

Logging- how do we check those values you mention for our shooter?

Without knowing your motor types, you’ll need something along the lines of .getVelocity(). The simplest way to log is to put that for each shooter motor on SmartDashboard and record the dashboard with a GoPro.

posts.name: Sherry Betcher
posts.cooked: Thanks to the expertise & Gracious Professionalism of 1701 Robocubs , we’re all set! The difference was, it was intaking differently from the source than our human player. It seems kind of obvious in hindsight. So an adjustment needed to be made to the speed  of our intake

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Sounds like you have high resistance somewhere in  your system…  I would check the strip length on the Rev PDH .  It needs 3/4" of bare wire.  Crazy long.

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
